Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: The mentee has a small question about terminology that isn't blocking their work.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I stared at my screen, headset pressing into my ear, as Mr. Jenkins’ voice crackled through the line. He was furious, demanding to know why our “exclusive offer” was any different from the last three he’d received. My script felt useless; he wanted real answers, not rehearsed lines. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Handle every objection, don’t escalate unless absolutely necessary.” I tried to keep my voice steady, but my mind kept drifting to the email draft open in another window—a question for my mentor about a term in our latest project. It wasn’t urgent, but I’d been told to communicate any challenge, no matter how small, as soon as it arose. I felt torn. If I paused to send the email, I’d be distracted from Mr. Jenkins, risking a complaint. But if I waited, I’d be letting my mentor down, not living up to the expectations set for me as a proactive mentee. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, heart pounding, caught between two roles that suddenly felt impossible to balance.
